content.value: In a mesmerizing 56 seconds of the semifinals at the 2024 World Crokinole Championship, Connor Reinman and Jason Slater simultaneously secured perfect rounds.

value.figcaption: Double perfect round. Watch on YouTube.

content.value: Technically speaking, they each flicked a 3.2cm disc 30cm across a board into a 3.5cm hole (just 9% wider than the disc itself) eight times in a row. In game terms, they made eight open 20s each; a rare gem of Crokinole perfection on display when the stakes couldn't be higher.

How did we get here? How rare is a perfect round? Is Reinman vs. Slater the modern day Magic vs. Bird? Was this one of those obscure new Olympic events? You may even be wondering, “wtf is Crokinole?” If you find yourself sitting with any of these questions, then you’ve come to the right place.
This is a story about Crokinole. I am Russell Samora. You are reading this now. Read on for answers to all these questions and much more.
20-second history

If you are from the southern region of the Canadian province of Ontario, you may already be well-versed in Crokinole. But for the uninitiated, Crokinole is like a mashup of shuffleboard and curling, played on a tabletop board. It's been around since the 19th century but has seen a steady rise in global popularity in recent years.

30-second game overview

Players take turns flicking discs toward the center, aiming to score high while knocking their opponent’s discs into lower zones or off the board. A shot must hit an opponent’s disc if one is present; otherwise, it must land in the inner circle (or score a 20 in the center hole). The round winner is whoever has the most points, and games consist of multiple rounds. Watch this video for a more thorough rules explanation.

The top players over the past decade
Connor Reinman, the back-to-back world champion, and Justin Slater, the perennial powerhouse, are arguably the greatest players on the Crokinole world stage right now.
But how good are they? Let's start by looking at their open 20 skills, an indispensable part of success.
<mark>[table of open 20% in the 2023-2024 season]</mark>
Both Reinman and Slater are among the best competitive players at open 20s, making 66% and 75% respectively. Top competitive players make about 55% of open 20s in games.

For a competitive player, making eight straight open 20s in live-game action should happen about 1 in every 150 rounds. That is like an NBA player making 20 straight free throws during the season. Not impossible, but definitely not common either.
Not top players

But it’s just flicking a little disc across a small table, how hard can it be, right? Let's contextualize their skill by comparing it to some “ordinary” folks. Here is some data from my local club of non-competitive players. Our experience ranges from a handful to hundreds of games.

Some other hed

Keep in mind this is in-game play, where a player’s open 20 rhythm is broken up by various other types of shots. In a vacuum, they can do some pretty impressive things. Take Shawn Hagarty for example, who recently set an unofficial world record of 64 straight open 20s.

content.value: Our theoretical scenarios give us a pretty good sense of the odds of seeing this phenomenon. Real games are much more nuanced and complex. A player — or their opponent — often misses quite early.
<mark>[histogram when people tend to miss - first to miss data]</mark>

But a miss doesn’t fully close the door on a perfect round. In this much more common scenario, a perfect round is more likely to come from a combination of open and ricochet 20s that keep the dream alive. [tbd talk about discs on the board and it being the other big/fun part of the game - that’s when it gets interesting]. That being said, we are far more likely to see a perfect round when two great players go against each other, keeping the discs on the board to a minimum.
And no, Crokinole isn’t an Olympic sport. Yet.

text.value: Recreational open 20 success rates are based on observations of 600 open 20 attempts from 10 individuals with at least 50 attempts each.
